mainmatter.p: Let \sim∼\sim∼ be an equivalence relation on a set AAAA. For any element a \in Aa∈Aa \in Aa∈A, the equivalence class of aaaa is the set [a] = \set {b \in A:b \sim a}[a]={ b∈A:b∼a }[a] = \set {b \in A:b \sim a}[a]={b∈A:b∼a}. The set of all equivalence classes is denoted by A/ \simA/∼A/ \simA/∼, which is called the quotient set of AAAA by \sim∼\sim∼. The equivalence class of aaaa is also denoted by \overline {a}a‾\overline {a}a.
Refer to Category Theory for Scientists.

Set is a common concept in mathematics. This post is a brief introduction to set theory aimed at complete all basic knowledge of set theory. The following topics will be covered
Zermelo-Fraenkel Axioms and Axiom of Choice
Cardinality
Set theory constructions
In this post, we use the Zermelo-Fraenkel set theory with the Axiom of Choice (ZFC).

ZFC is the abbreviation of Zermelo-Fraenkel set theory with the Axiom of Choice. The axioms of ZFC are listed below. Axiom of Extensionality: Two sets are equal if and only if they have the same elements. Axiom of Pairing: For any two sets aaaa and bbbb, there exists a set \{ a,b \}{a,b}\{ a,b \}{a,b} whose elements are exactly aaaa and bbbb. Axiom schema of Separation: Let PPPP is a property of sets. P(u)P(u)P(u)P(u) means uuuu satisfies the property PPPP. then for any set XXXX exists Y = \{ u \in X | P(u) \}Y={u∈X∣P(u)}Y = \{ u \in X | P(u) \}Y={u∈X∣P(u)}. Axiom of Union: For any set XXXX (a family of sets), exists union set \bigcup X : \equiv \{ u: \exists v \in X \text { such that } u \in v \}⋃X:≡{u:∃v∈X such that u∈v}\bigcup X : \equiv \{ u: \exists v \in X \text { such that } u \in v \}⋃X:≡{u:∃v∈X such that u∈v}. Axiom of Power Set: For any set XXXX, exists the power P(X) : \equiv \{ Y:Y \subseteq X \}P(X):≡{Y:Y⊆X}P(X) : \equiv \{ Y:Y \subseteq X \}P(X):≡{Y:Y⊆X}. Axiom of Infinity: There exists a set \omegaω\omegaω such that \emptyset \in \omega∅∈ω\emptyset \in \omega∅∈ω and for any x \in \omegax∈ωx \in \omegax∈ω, x \cup \{ x \} \in \omegax∪{x}∈ωx \cup \{ x \} \in \omegax∪{x}∈ω. Axiom of Regularity: For any non-empty set there is a minimal element with respect to the membership relation. Axiom schema of Replacement: Let FFFF be a function where \text {dom } f = Xdom f=X\text {dom } f = Xdom f=X, then for any set XXXX exists a set Y = \{ F(x):x \in X \}Y={F(x):x∈X}Y = \{ F(x):x \in X \}Y={F(x):x∈X}. This function is not the normal function but some logical stuff. Axiom of Choice: For any family of non-empty sets XXXX, there exists a function f:X \to \bigcup Xf:X→⋃Xf:X \to \bigcup Xf:X→⋃X such that for any x \in Xx∈Xx \in Xx∈X, f(x) \in xf(x)∈xf(x) \in xf(x)∈x.
Let (X_i)_{i \in I}(Xi)i∈I(X_i)_{i \in I}(Xi​)i∈I​ be a family of sets.

p.tex: \bigcup _{i \in I}X_i = \set {x: \exists i \in I \text { such that } x \in X_i} ⋃i∈IXi={ x:∃i∈I such that x∈Xi } \bigcup _{i \in I}X_i = \set {x: \exists i \in I \text { such that } x \in X_i} i∈I⋃​Xi​={x:∃i∈I such that x∈Xi​}

mainmatter.p: \bigcap _{i \in I}X_i = \set {x: \forall i \in I, x \in X_i} ⋂i∈IXi={ x:∀i∈I,x∈Xi } \bigcap _{i \in I}X_i = \set {x: \forall i \in I, x \in X_i} i∈I⋂​Xi​={x:∀i∈I,x∈Xi​} Note that I \neq \emptysetI≠∅I \neq \emptysetI=∅ here.

p.tex: \bigsqcup _{i \in I}X_i = \set {(x,i):x \in X_i, i \in I} ⨆i∈IXi={ (x,i):x∈Xi,i∈I } \bigsqcup _{i \in I}X_i = \set {(x,i):x \in X_i, i \in I} i∈I⨆​Xi​={(x,i):x∈Xi​,i∈I}

\prod _{i \in I}X_i = \set {(x_i)_{i \in I}: \forall i \in I, x_i \in X_i} ∏i∈IXi={ (xi)i∈I:∀i∈I,xi∈Xi } \prod _{i \in I}X_i = \set {(x_i)_{i \in I}: \forall i \in I, x_i \in X_i} i∈I∏​Xi​={(xi​)i∈I​:∀i∈I,xi​∈Xi​}

mainmatter.p: And principles of set theory
Two sets are equal if and only if they have the same elements.
Given a set AAAA and a property P(x)P(x)P(x)P(x), there exists a set BBBB such that x \in B \iff x \in A \land P(x)x∈B  ⟺  x∈A∧P(x)x \in B \iff x \in A \land P(x)x∈B⟺x∈A∧P(x).
We then define the Cartesian product of two sets
Given two sets AAAA and BBBB, the Cartesian product A \times BA×BA \times BA×B is the set of all ordered pairs (a,b)(a,b)(a,b)(a,b) where a \in Aa∈Aa \in Aa∈A and b \in Bb∈Bb \in Bb∈B.
With the Cartesian product, we can define the relation

A relation RRRR is a subset of the Cartesian product of two sets AAAA and BBBB, i.e. R \subseteq A \times BR⊆A×BR \subseteq A \times BR⊆A×B. If (a,b) \in R(a,b)∈R(a,b) \in R(a,b)∈R, we write aRbaRbaRbaRb. A relation that between XXXX and itself is called homogeneous relation.

An equivalence relation RRRR on a set AAAA is a relation that is reflexive, symmetric, and transitive. Reflexive: \forall x \in A, xRx∀x∈A,xRx\forall x \in A, xRx∀x∈A,xRx Symmetric: \forall x,y \in A, xRy \implies yRx∀x,y∈A,xRy  ⟹  yRx\forall x,y \in A, xRy \implies yRx∀x,y∈A,xRy⟹yRx Transitive: \forall x,y,z \in A, xRy \land yRz \implies xRz∀x,y,z∈A,xRy∧yRz  ⟹  xRz\forall x,y,z \in A, xRy \land yRz \implies xRz∀x,y,z∈A,xRy∧yRz⟹xRz We often denote the equivalence relation by \sim∼\sim∼.

Let \sim∼\sim∼ be an equivalence relation on a set AAAA. For any element a \in Aa∈Aa \in Aa∈A, the equivalence class of aaaa is the set [a] = \set {b \in A:b \sim a}[a]={ b∈A:b∼a }[a] = \set {b \in A:b \sim a}[a]={b∈A:b∼a}. The set of all equivalence classes is denoted by A/ \simA/∼A/ \simA/∼, which is called the quotient set of AAAA by \sim∼\sim∼. The equivalence class of aaaa is also denoted by \overline {a}a‾\overline {a}a.
One of the most important relations is the order relation. The basic order relation is the preorder.
A preorder is a relation \leq≤\leq≤ that is reflexive and transitive. Reflexive: a \leq aa≤aa \leq aa≤a Transitive: a \leq ba≤ba \leq ba≤b and b \leq cb≤cb \leq cb≤c implies a \leq ca≤ca \leq ca≤c

A (non-strict) partial order is a relation \leq≤\leq≤ that is reflexive, antisymmetric and transitive. Reflexive: a \leq aa≤aa \leq aa≤a Antisymmetric: a \leq ba≤ba \leq ba≤b and b \leq ab≤ab \leq ab≤a implies a=ba=ba=ba=b Transitive: a \leq ba≤ba \leq ba≤b and b \leq cb≤cb \leq cb≤c implies a \leq ca≤ca \leq ca≤c A non-strict partial order is also known as an antisymmetric preorder.
And the strict partial order (notice the difference between asymmetric and antisymmetric)

A strict partial order is a relation <<<< that is irreflexive, asymmetric and transitive. Irreflexive: \neg (a¬(a<a)\neg (a<a)¬(a<a) Asymmetric: aa<ba<ba<b implies \neg (b¬(b<a)\neg (b<a)¬(b<a) Transitive: aa<ba<ba<b and bb<cb<cb<c implies aa<ca<ca<c
With the definition of order, we can define the upper bound and lower bound

Let a subset SSSS of a partially ordered set (P, \leq )(P,≤)(P, \leq )(P,≤), SSSS is bounded above if there exists x \in Px∈Px \in Px∈P such that \forall y \in S, y \leq x∀y∈S,y≤x\forall y \in S, y \leq x∀y∈S,y≤x. And xxxx is called an upper bound of SSSS. Dually, SSSS is bounded below if there exists x \in Px∈Px \in Px∈P such that \forall y \in S, x \leq y∀y∈S,x≤y\forall y \in S, x \leq y∀y∈S,x≤y. And xxxx is called a lower bound of SSSS.
An element x \in Px∈Px \in Px∈P is a supremum of SSSS, if for all upper bounds z \in Pz∈Pz \in Pz∈P of SSSS, x \leq zx≤zx \leq zx≤z. Denoted as x = \sup Sx=sup⁡Sx = \sup Sx=supS.
An element x \in Px∈Px \in Px∈P is a infimum of SSSS, if for all lower bounds z \in Pz∈Pz \in Pz∈P of SSSS, z \leq xz≤xz \leq xz≤x. Denoted as x = \inf Sx=inf⁡Sx = \inf Sx=infS.

Let XXXX and YYYY be sets then a function f:X \to Yf:X→Yf:X \to Yf:X→Y is a mapping that sends each element of XXXX to a unique element of YYYY, denoted by f(x) = yf(x)=yf(x) = yf(x)=y. Function is a special case of relation, and it is a relation that is left-total and right-unique. f \in X \times Y \text { and } \forall x \in X, \exists ! y \in Y, (x,y) \in f f∈X×Y and ∀x∈X,∃!y∈Y,(x,y)∈f f \in X \times Y \text { and } \forall x \in X, \exists ! y \in Y, (x,y) \in f f∈X×Y and ∀x∈X,∃!y∈Y,(x,y)∈f XXXX is said to be the domain of ffff and YYYY is said to be the codomain of ffff, where we denote X = \text {dom } fX=dom fX = \text {dom } fX=dom f and Y = \text {cod } fY=cod fY = \text {cod } fY=cod f.

Two functions f:X \to Yf:X→Yf:X \to Yf:X→Y and g:Y \to Zg:Y→Zg:Y \to Zg:Y→Z can be composed to form a new function g \circ f : X \to Zg∘f:X→Zg \circ f : X \to Zg∘f:X→Z, where the composition is defined by (g \circ f)(x) = g(f(x)) (g∘f)(x)=g(f(x)) (g \circ f)(x) = g(f(x)) (g∘f)(x)=g(f(x))
The set of all functions from XXXX to YYYY is denoted by \hom _ \text {set} (X, Y)hom⁡set(X,Y)\hom _ \text {set} (X, Y)homset​(X,Y).
The isomorphism function is defined as follows

Let XXXX and YYYY be sets and f: X \to Yf:X→Yf: X \to Yf:X→Y be a function. The function ffff is called an isomorphism if it is both injective and surjective. In other words, there exists a function g: Y \to Xg:Y→Xg: Y \to Xg:Y→X such that g \circ f = \text {id} _X \text { and } f \circ g = \text {id} _Y g∘f=idX and f∘g=idY g \circ f = \text {id} _X \text { and } f \circ g = \text {id} _Y g∘f=idX​ and f∘g=idY​ where \text {id} _XidX\text {id} _XidX​ and \text {id} _YidY\text {id} _YidY​ are the identity functions on XXXX and YYYY respectively. And we say ffff is invertible and gggg is the inverse of ffff. If there is a isomorphism between XXXX and YYYY, we say XXXX and YYYY are isomorphic, denoted by X \cong YX≅YX \cong YX≅Y. Isomorphism is an equivalence relation.
With isomorphism, we can define the cardinality of a set. Two isomorphic sets have the same cardinality.

Let XXXX be a set and n \in \mathbb {N}n∈Nn \in \mathbb {N}n∈N. AAAA si said to have cardinality nnnn, denoted by |A|= n∣A∣=n |A|= n∣A∣=n, if there exists an isomorphism between AAAA and S_n = \{ 1,2, \cdots ,n \}Sn={1,2,⋯ ,n}S_n = \{ 1,2, \cdots ,n \}Sn​={1,2,⋯,n}. If AAAA has finite cardinality, we say AAAA is finite, otherwise we say AAAA is infinite, denoted by |A| \geq \infty∣A∣≥∞|A| \geq \infty∣A∣≥∞.
The next topic is the product of sets

Let XXXX and YYYY be sets, then the Cartesian product of XXXX and YYYY is the set X \times Y = \set {(x,y) \mid x \in X \text { and } y \in Y} X×Y={ (x,y)∣x∈X and y∈Y } X \times Y = \set {(x,y) \mid x \in X \text { and } y \in Y} X×Y={(x,y)∣x∈X and y∈Y} There are two natural projections from the Cartesian product to the original sets, namely \pi _1 : X \times Y \to X \text { and } \pi _2 : X \times Y \to Y π1:X×Y→X and π2:X×Y→Y \pi _1 : X \times Y \to X \text { and } \pi _2 : X \times Y \to Y π1​:X×Y→X and π2​:X×Y→Y
This leads to an improtant concept named universal property.

frontmatter.title: Universal Property for Product of Sets

mainmatter.p: Let XXXX and YYYY be sets. For any set AAAA and function f: A \to Xf:A→Xf: A \to Xf:A→X and g: A \to Yg:A→Yg: A \to Yg:A→Y, there exists a unique function h: A \to X \times Yh:A→X×Yh: A \to X \times Yh:A→X×Y such that the following diagram commutes: \usepackage {tikz-cd} \usepackage {amssymb} \begin {tikzcd} & {X \times Y} \\ X && Y \\ & A \arrow ["{ \pi _1}"', from=1-2, to=2-1] \arrow ["{ \pi _2}", from=1-2, to=2-3] \arrow ["f", from=3-2, to=2-1] \arrow ["g"', from=3-2, to=2-3] \arrow ["{ \exists !}", dashed, from=3-2, to=1-2] \end {tikzcd} We might denote the unique function by \langle f,g \rangle : A \to X \times Y⟨f,g⟩:A→X×Y\langle f,g \rangle : A \to X \times Y⟨f,g⟩:A→X×Y. It is sufficient to define \langle f,g \rangle (a) = (f(a),g(a))⟨f,g⟩(a)=(f(a),g(a))\langle f,g \rangle (a) = (f(a),g(a))⟨f,g⟩(a)=(f(a),g(a)) for all a \in Aa∈Aa \in Aa∈A as the unique function.
Dual to the product of sets, we have the coproduct of sets

Let XXXX and YYYY be sets, then the coproduct of XXXX and YYYY is defined as the disjoint union of XXXX and YYYY, denoted by X \sqcup YX⊔YX \sqcup YX⊔Y. There are two natural injections from the original sets to the coproduct, namely i_1 : X \to X \sqcup Y \text { and } i_2 : Y \to X \sqcup Y i1:X→X⊔Y and i2:Y→X⊔Y i_1 : X \to X \sqcup Y \text { and } i_2 : Y \to X \sqcup Y i1​:X→X⊔Y and i2​:Y→X⊔Y

frontmatter.title: Universal Property for Coproduct of Sets

mainmatter.p: In this section we discuss the limits of variously-shaped diagrams of sets.

Suppose we have sets XXXX, YYYY, and ZZZZ and functions f : X \to Zf:X→Zf : X \to Zf:X→Z and g : Y \to Zg:Y→Zg : Y \to Zg:Y→Z. \usepackage {tikz-cd} \usepackage {amssymb} \begin {tikzcd} & Y \\ X & Z \arrow ["f"', from=2-1, to=2-2] \arrow ["g", from=1-2, to=2-2] \end {tikzcd} Its fiber product is the set X \times _Z Y = \{ (x,w,y) \mid f(x) = w = g(y) \} X×ZY={(x,w,y)∣f(x)=w=g(y)} X \times _Z Y = \{ (x,w,y) \mid f(x) = w = g(y) \} X×Z​Y={(x,w,y)∣f(x)=w=g(y)} There are obvious projections \pi _1 : X \times _Z Y \to X \text { and } \pi _2 : X \times _Z Y \to Y π1:X×ZY→X and π2:X×ZY→Y \pi _1 : X \times _Z Y \to X \text { and } \pi _2 : X \times _Z Y \to Y π1​:X×Z​Y→X and π2​:X×Z​Y→Y such that the following diagram commutes (W = X \times _Z YW=X×ZYW = X \times _Z YW=X×Z​Y): \usepackage {tikz-cd} \usepackage {amssymb} \begin {tikzcd} W & Y \\ X & Z \arrow ["f"', from=2-1, to=2-2] \arrow ["g", from=1-2, to=2-2] \arrow ["{ \pi _2}", from=1-1, to=1-2] \arrow ["{ \pi _1}"', from=1-1, to=2-1] \arrow [" \lrcorner "{anchor=center, pos=0.125}, draw=none, from=1-1, to=2-2] \end {tikzcd} The pullback is defined to be any set W \cong X \times _Z YW≅X×ZYW \cong X \times _Z YW≅X×Z​Y The corner symbol indicates WWWW is a pullback
The pullback also satisfies the universal property.

An equivalence relation RRRR on a set AAAA is a relation that is reflexive, symmetric, and transitive. Reflexive: \forall x \in A, xRx∀x∈A,xRx\forall x \in A, xRx∀x∈A,xRx Symmetric: \forall x,y \in A, xRy \implies yRx∀x,y∈A,xRy  ⟹  yRx\forall x,y \in A, xRy \implies yRx∀x,y∈A,xRy⟹yRx Transitive: \forall x,y,z \in A, xRy \land yRz \implies xRz∀x,y,z∈A,xRy∧yRz  ⟹  xRz\forall x,y,z \in A, xRy \land yRz \implies xRz∀x,y,z∈A,xRy∧yRz⟹xRz We often denote the equivalence relation by \sim∼\sim∼.
